text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to state that only courts, not arbitral tribunals, can decide jurisdictional validity, ignoring the competence-competence principle. The candidate answer explicitly and correctly argues the opposite: it states that the foundational argument is that the arbitral tribunal itself had the authority to determine its own jurisdiction (competence-competence), citing French law (Article 1465 CPC) and US precedent (First Options). Therefore, the candidate answer directly contradicts the premise of the negative criterion, meaning the criterion is satisfied by being refuted.", "criterion_id": "9495db3e-2861-45da-a1e2-0b1f7bdac2f6"}
